JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;Giovanni Bonello;Ján Šikuta;Lech Garlicki;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza
TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was represented before the ORG by Mr H Tepe , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , Ms J PERSON of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
The applicant came to GPE in DATE . He was granted leave to enter and remain , which permitted him to work in GPE . On DATE he was granted Indefinite Leave to Remain .
In DATE the applicant married a NORP citizen . His wife was born in GPE in DATE but she came to GPE when she was DATE , while GPE was still under NORP control . She speaks LANGUAGE .

The applicant and his wife have a daughter , who was born in GPE on DATE . She is a NORP citizen . She married in DATE and has CARDINAL children , born on DATE and CARDINAL DATE , who are also NORP citizens . Her husband 's family are NORP and she travels to GPE approximately once a year to visit them .

On DATE the applicant was convicted of the importation of controlled drugs . Together with CARDINAL accomplices , he had imported QUANTITY of pure heroin , worth GBP CARDINAL . Although it was the applicant 's first offence , the sentencing judge noted that he had organised the importation and although he had pleaded guilty , he had only done so at a late stage . He was sentenced to DATE imprisonment but was not recommended for deportation . He did not appeal against sentence or conviction .

On DATE the Secretary of ORG for ORG wrote to the applicant , asking him to submit reasons why he should not be deported . The applicant 's representations were considered but on DATE the Secretary of ORG advised the applicant that he intended to deport him on the ground that his deportation would be conducive to the public good . On DATE the applicant was issued with a Decision to Make a Deportation Order . The applicant appealed to ORG ( “ ORG ” ) . In a decision dated DATE , the ORG dismissed the appeal , holding , inter alia , that the applicant 's crime was too serious for his deportation to be found to be disproportionate , notwithstanding the interference with his private and family life in GPE . On DATE the ORG decided not to make an order for reconsideration . The applicant considered renewing his application to ORG , but counsel advised him that it would be virtually impossible to challenge the ORG 's decision .
On DATE the applicant was served with a deportation order . He was deported to GPE on DATE .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) of LAW DATE ( as amended by ORG ) provides that a person who is not a NORP citizen shall be liable to deportation from GPE if the Secretary of ORG deems his deportation to be conducive to the public good . Sections CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL of the Nationality , Immigration and Asylum Act DATE provide for a right of appeal against this decision on the grounds , inter alia , that the decision is incompatible with the Convention .

Section CARDINAL of LAW DATE provides that , in determining any question that arises in connection with a Convention right , courts and tribunals must take into account any case - law from this ORG so far as , in the opinion of the court or tribunal , it is relevant to the proceedings in which that question has arisen .
A person who has been deported may apply to have the deportation order revoked . LAW of ORG CARDINAL ( as amended ) provide that :
“ CARDINAL . An application for revocation of a deportation order will be considered in the light of all the circumstances including the following :
( i ) the grounds on which the order was made ;
( ii ) any representations made in support of revocation ;
( iii ) the interests of the community , including the maintenance of an effective immigration control ;
( iv ) the interests of the applicant , including any compassionate circumstances .
CARDINAL . In the case of an applicant who has been deported following conviction for a criminal offence continued exclusion

( i ) in the case of a conviction which is capable of being spent under LAW , unless the conviction is spent within the meaning of that LAW or , if the conviction is spent in DATE , DATE have elapsed since the making of the deportation order ; or
( ii ) in the case of a conviction not capable of being spent under that LAW , at any time , unless refusal to revoke the deportation order would be contrary to LAW or LAW .

will normally be the proper course . In other cases revocation of the order will not normally be authorised unless the situation has been materially altered , either by a change of circumstances since the order was made , or by fresh information coming to light which was not before , or the appellate authorities or the Secretary of ORG . The passage of time since the person was deported may also in itself amount to such a change of circumstances as to warrant revocation of the order .

CARDINAL . Revocation of a deportation order does not entitle the person concerned to re - enter GPE ; it renders him eligible to apply for admission under LAW . Application for revocation of the order may be made to ORG or direct to ORG . ”
